title: 112_s3333
content:
The "Data Security and Breach Notification Act of 2012" requires covered entities to protect electronic data containing personal information and notify individuals of any security breaches. The "Data Security and Breach Notification Act of 2012" mandates covered entities to notify individuals in the US of any security breaches involving personal information in electronic form. This includes informing law enforcement if necessary. The Data Security and Breach Notification Act of 2012 requires covered entities to notify individuals if their personal information has been accessed by an unauthorized person, exceeding 10,000 records. Third-party agents must also notify covered entities of any security breaches involving personal information stored or processed on their behalf. The Data Security and Breach Notification Act of 2012 mandates covered entities to inform individuals of unauthorized access to their personal information exceeding 10,000 records. Service providers are exempt from being considered third-party agents for breach notification purposes. If a service provider discovers a security breach involving personal information owned by a covered entity using their system, they must notify the initiating covered entity. Covered entities must promptly notify individuals of security breaches involving their personal information. If a service provider detects a breach, they must inform the covered entity who initiated the connection. The notification should be timely and made without unreasonable delay to assess the breach's extent and restore data system integrity. The data breach notification can be delayed for law enforcement or national security reasons. Law enforcement agencies can request a delay if it would impede an investigation, and the delay can be extended if necessary. National security reasons can also justify a delay in notification. If a Federal national security or homeland security agency deems that notifying about a data breach would threaten national security, the notification can be delayed upon their written request for a period they determine necessary. They can also extend the delay if needed. Method and Content of Notification for a security breach include written notification, telephone, or email/electronic means to the individual's postal address in the records of the covered entity. In the event of a security breach, notification should include the date of the breach, description of accessed personal information, and contact information for inquiries. Substitute notification may be provided by a covered entity if direct notification is not feasible due to excessive cost or lack of contact information for the individual. Substitute notification can be provided by a covered entity through various means, such as a notice on their website or through print and broadcast media. Covered entities complying with other federal laws regarding breach notifications are considered compliant with this section. SEC. 4. APPLICATION AND ENFORCEMENT. The requirements of sections 2 and 3 apply to persons, partnerships, or corporations under the authority of the Federal Trade Commission Act and common carriers subject to the Communications Act of 1934. Sections 222, 338, and 631 of the Communications Act do not apply to the information security practices of covered entities. The Federal Trade Commission enforces violations of sections 2 and 3 as unfair or deceptive acts. The Commission has the same enforcement powers as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Act enforces penalties and privileges for violations of sections 3 and 4. The maximum civil penalty for violations of section 2 is $500,000 for related acts, and for violations of section 3 is $500,000 for a single breach of security. No private cause of action is allowed under this Act. No private cause of action is allowed for violations of this Act. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "breach of security" refers to unauthorized access and acquisition of data containing personal information. The "Commission" refers to the Federal Trade Commission. A "covered entity" includes various commercial entities that acquire, maintain, store, or utilize personal information, excluding financial institutions under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. The term "personal information" refers to an individual's first name or initial. Data in electronic form includes electronically stored data on computer systems and mass storage devices. Covered entities are subject to regulations under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act. Personal information includes an individual's first name or initial, along with specific data elements such as Social Security number, driver's license number, financial account number, and more. Exclusions apply to public record information. Personal information excludes publicly available information and encrypted, redacted, or secured data. Service provider refers to entities offering electronic data services. Entities providing transmission, routing, storage, or connections to electronic data without selecting or modifying content, and not being the sender or intended recipient, are considered service providers under the Act. SEC. 6. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS.

This Act preempts any state laws relating to data protection or breach notification.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act will take effect one year after enactment.
